description.narrative: (1) # of provinces having CD plan and strategies (2) # of Provincial Strategic Plans (PSPs) prepared (3) # of Provincial Development Plans (PDPs) prepared with ASGP support through a structured and participatory process (4) # of provinces with Citizen Service Centers for improved access to information and responsive governance (5) # of PGOs and DGOs with functioning admin. management system in accordance with IDLG operating guidelines (6) # of PCs trained in exercising oversight and representative functions in compliance with PC law

comment.narrative: 2.1. 81% in the PGOs and 72% in the DGOs 2.2. 3% in the PGOs and 0% in the DGOs 2.3. 59% in the PGOs and 46% in the DGOs 2.4. 8 PGOs and 3 DGOs 2.5. GOFORGOLD performance measurement system developed but not utilized at all due to its abstract and resourece-demanding nature 2.6. 4 PGOs 2.7. PSPs prepared in 7 provinces. PDPs prepared in all the provinces 2.8. None of the PGOs have liquidated LOA advances on time (affected by delays in Kabul) 2.9. GDCLCA does not have its page on the IDLG website 2.10. 27 2.11. 24

2.1 Number of tashkeel positions filled in PGOs and targeted DGOs. 95% of tashkeel positions filled in the Provincial Governor’s Office (PGOs). Female tashkeel constitute 3% of all employed tashkeel in the PGO. Female tashkeel constitute 5% of all employed tashkeel in the PGO 15 PGOs and 15 District Governors (DGOs) implement promotional/motivational activities to advocate for female recruitment. 2.2: 14 PGO HR plans includes Gender Mainstreaming (GM) session. 2.3: 50% of PGO and 25% 0f targeted DGO tashkeel staff trained on Office Manual. 2.4: Ten PGOs and five DGOs with a separate female toilet facility. 2.5: 23 PGOs have Provincial Gender Committees to support gender sensitive service delivery. 2.6:10 PGOs Implement Communication Strategies. 2.7: 34 Provinces Have Completed Provincial Development Plan (PDPs) and 10 Have Current and Completed Provincial Strategic Plans (PSPs). 2.8: 13 PGOs hold PDP conferences/ workshops/initiatives to launch/ develop the PDP. 2.9: 10 PGOs include tashkeel staff who receive Public Financial Management training during 2014. 2.10: All Provincial Council (PCs) hold twice monthly meetings with the PGO and also hold monthly internal meetings. 2.11: 306 PC members and 46 tashkeel staff receive training and orientation on PC law and responsibilities, relationship with line departments 2.12: 17 PCs (50%) include members that undertake monitoring missions to districts

2.1. 95% of tashkeel positions filled in the PGOs, Female tashkeel constitute 4% of all PGO employed tashkeel. 9 PGOs implement promotional/motivational activities to advocate for female recruitment. 2.2. 8 PGO HR plans includes GM session. 2.3. 30% of PGO personnel have received training on Office Manual 2.4. Fifteen PGOs - On target. Cumulative target. 2.5. Off target, due to PGOs focus on other interests. Mitigating measures include support to other gender initiatives and gender policy, as outlined in the report. 2.6. On target. Cumulative target. 22 PGOs Have Communication Strategies: 2.7. On Target. Provinces Have Completed PDPs and PSPs: 34 Provinces Have Completed PDPs and five Have Completed PSPs. 2.8. On target. Number of PGOs that hold PDP conferences/ workshops/initiatives to launch/ develop the PDP: 23 PGOs. 2.9. On Target. PGOs with tashkeel staff who receive Public Financial Management training in line with MOF policy. 2.10. On Target. 34 PCs hold 102 IMs. 34 PCs hold 198 internal meetings (IMs) following the rules and procedures. 2.11. On Target. 120 PC members receive CD training during the quarter, and 240 total during 2015. 2.12. 17 PCs undertake 102 monitoring mission to 34 districts.

title.narrative: Strengthening the resilience of rural livelihood options

description.narrative: Strengthening the resilience of rural livelihood options for Afghan communities in Panjshir, Balkh, Uruzgan and Herat Provinces to manage climate change-induced disaster risks.
Strengthening the resilience of rural livelihood options for Afghan communities.

activity-description.narrative: Integration of climate change in local planning, alternative livelihood and irrigation infrastructure improvement at Panjshir, Hirat, Balkh and Uruzgan provinces.
Integration of climate change in local planning, alternative livelihood and irrigation infrastructure improvement at Panjshir, Hirat, Balkh and Uruzgan provinces.

description.narrative: Strengthening the resilience of rural livelihood options for Afghan communities in Panjshir, Balkh, Uruzgan and Herat Provinces to manage climate change-induced disaster risks

1.Capacity of MAIL as per capacity assessment scorecard (baseline: 3; target: 4 )
2. Domestic finance committed to the relevant institutions to integrate climate change information in development planning

comment.narrative:
3
Minimal

To achieve the Capacity Scorecard score of 4
Domestic target financing is $10 million per year

A ban on Government recruitments was imposed soon after the change of presidency in the country on 31 September 2014 until the nomination and appointment of the new Minister, in May, 2015. Because of this, the MAIL could only hire project manager and senior irrigation engineer but not the full relevant technical team, according to schedule. Hence, the results expected during the first year of implementation were not met.

description.narrative: Climate change risk and variability integrated into local planning and budgeting processes

Amount of budget allocated specifically for climate change adaptation measures in development plans at the provincial level and community development plans (CDCs)
Extent to which climate change information and adaptation measures are incorporated into MAIL local development plans in 4 provinces
Number of climate change scenarios developed for the agriculture sector in selected provinces
Number of MAIL officials, farmers, and pastoralists trained on climate risk information and appropriate response measures

comment.narrative:
Capacity for climate-related analysis and forward planning is limited at national and sub-national level.
Institutional capacity for cross-sectoral climate change planning is negligible
0
0

By end of project, 15 communities and 4 provincial task teams have been trained in and use climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated area-based planning approach.
Climate resilient investment strategies based on integrated climate resilient development plans are in place and attracting funding.
4 climate change scenarios developed
At least 250 MAIL officials, farmers, and pastoralists trained

description.narrative: Rural income and livelihood opportunities for vulnerable communities enhanced and diversified

comment.narrative:
Women and Farmers currently constrained by limited access to and knowledge of diversified livelihood opportunities.
Currently there is a lack of access to training, markets, raw materials and financing.

By the end of the project local administration task teams are able to deliver livelihood diversification support to women and SMEs

description.narrative:
Crop productivity level from irrigated agriculture (X tons of crops per hectare)
Amount of crops and livelihoods assets damaged by floods or drought in the targeted areas
Number of small-scale storage reservoirs built in selected river sub-basins
Number of communities where micro-water harvesting techniques are introduced

comment.narrative:
Very limited capacity for applying climate resilient agriculture
Informal coping strategies are in use in target areas, no formal infrastructure risk reducing/insurance approaches yet in place due to lack of knowledge and hazard information in target areas

0
0
0

By the end of the project, climate resilient agricultural production has increased by 10% in target areas compared to baseline (1t/ha maize) adjusted for rainfall.
By the end of the project at least 25% agricultural infrastructure in the target communities is improved to insure against the inherent uncertainty of climate change

description.narrative: Enabling the Ministry of Economy to lead on coordinating & monitoring the SDGs on behalf of the Government of Afghanistan.
MoEC is structurally organized to lead on SDGs coordination, planning and monitoring

SDGs are successfully nationalized, aligned with the national development plans and linked with the budgeting process process and second ANDS.
